docs.lead_paragraph: Democracy," Marian Wright Edelman will tell you, "is not a spectator sport." Ms. Edelman is the passionate and prodigiously energetic president of the Children's Defense Fund. She speaks at lightning speed, trying to get everything said as quickly as possible, a long-distance runner maintaining a sprinter's pace. It's as if she were afraid that time itself was conspiring to limit her efforts on behalf of the nation's children.

docs.lead_paragraph: Days after Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield received New York State approval to establish a for-profit subsidiary, legislative and consumer watchdog groups raised the issue of a lucrative payback to the public as part of the package. The goal is the same in a number of other states, with officials demanding that Blue Cross and Blue Shield companies turn over hundreds of millions of dollars to charities or state treasuries as the price of converting their not-for-profit health care businesses into for-profit enterprises.

headline.main: Blue Cross Groups Seek Profit, And States Ask Share of Riches

docs.lead_paragraph: Election-year politics has propelled health care back to the top of the Congressional agenda, but it is not clear whether politics will speed or hinder the passage of legislation to make health insurance more readily available to millions of Americans. In any election year, Republicans and Democrats seek tangible accomplishments, and this year, when many American workers are worried about job security, health insurance proposals appeal to voters and politicians alike.

headline.main: Politics and the Health Care Bill

docs.lead_paragraph: Coal mining, poverty, old cars on concrete blocks, children running around barefoot: West Virginians know too well the outside world's perception of their state. Eleanor Milliken, a retired inspector for Westinghouse, says she just laughs now when her son-in-law from Silver Spring, Md., says, "You can tell girls from West Virginia because they have no teeth."

headline.main: West Virginia Sheds Image and Opens for Business

docs.lead_paragraph: When business improvement districts were born a decade ago, their supporters saw these self-taxing entities as vehicles for delivering basic services more efficiently -- and more cheaply -- than the city. Unencumbered by a unionized work force, many B.I.D.'s have been able to provide security and sanitation at a third of what it would cost the city. That is, until now. Since last June, Local 210 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters has tried to unionize workers in four large Manhattan B.I.D.'s: the Grand Central Partnership; 34th Street; Fifth Avenue Association, and Fashion District. It succeeded only once. 34th Street Partnership sanitation workers approved the local, but its contract negotiations have been deadlocked since November over wage increases and health benefits.

docs.lead_paragraph: While advocates for the poor say that more social-service programs mean more people turning their lives around, city leaders here have a different perspective: they say that more social service programs drain the economy, breed dependency and mean more poor people moving to Hartford, where one in four people is already on welfare. Accordingly, the City Council has taken what many consider a hard-line approach to stem the growth of poverty: a six-month moratorium on all new homeless shelters, rehabilitation homes and other treatment or social-service centers.

headline.main: Fighting Poverty Programs;Hartford Faces Vote to Bar New Nonprofit Services

docs.lead_paragraph: The young man in the brown belt whom she knew only as Lou jumped backward and touched the bridge of his nose. His fingers came away bloody. "I'm sorry, oh, I'm sorry," Celita Schutz said. Her voice was just loud enough to disturb the Saturday morning class in the frill-free Kokushi Dojo above the Ford dealership here. Small boys in white beginner's belts stopped grappling, and the sensei, Nagayasu Ogasawara, padded over. And then everyone stopped breathing.

headline.main: Accepting the Hard Knocks Is Only a Part of a Grappling Passion

docs.lead_paragraph: CONNECTICUT'S biggest money givers -- its businesses -- are having a hard time meeting demand. The state's largest corporations did give away millions of dollars in 1995, but the pot may be shrinking as the needs keep growing. Corporate grant makers say they are proud their budgets have remained largely stable in the past few years, but they say continuing cutbacks by Washington and by Hartford will mean even more requests than the thousands they already receive each year.

headline.main: Corporate Giving, Falling Behind as the Needs Grow

docs.lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about corporate medical benefits for executives and rank-and-file workers misstated the relationship of two executives in the Gannett Company, one of the companies cited. John J. Curley, the chief executive, is the brother of Thomas Curley, the publisher of USA Today, which is owned by Gannett.

docs.lead_paragraph: Donald DiFrancesco, president of the State Senate, said yesterday that he did not have enough votes to win passage of the latest proposal to pay for hospital care for uninsured New Jerseyans. Under the plan, so-called charity care would have been reduced by $125, and the state would have continued to draw upon the unemployment insurance fund. Mr. DiFrancesco, of Scotch Plains, blamed Democrats for blocking the plan but refused to say how many members of his Republican majority also failed to back the bill.

headline.main: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Charity Care Measure Fails
